captions.text:
[Robert Zubrin]
Mars is the next logical step
In our space program
It's the challenge that's been staring us in the face
For the past 30 years
It has water, it has carbon,
It has a 24 hour day
It has geothermal energy
Mars is a place we can settle

[Carl Sagan]
There is a giant rift in its surface
5,000 kilometers long
There is a volcano as wide as Arizona

[Zubrin]
So there's the choice in life
One either grows or one decays
Grow or die
I think we should grow

[Sagan]
Mars is a world of wonders

[Brian Cox]
It has canyons, river valleys,
and giant ice sheets

[Sagan]
Mars is a world of wonders

[Zubrin]
It shouldn't be humans to Mars in 50 years
It should be humans to Mars in 10
We either muster the courage to go
Or we risk the possibility of stagnation and decay
We've got cosmic radiation
Zero gravity
Martian dust storms
Back contamination
But these are dragons that we can take on

[Sagan]
In our time we have sifted
The sands of Mars
Established a presence there
And fulfilled a century of dreams

[Cox]
The Mars rovers have really
Captured our imaginations
They genuinely are explorers
In the old-fashioned sense

[Zubrin]
If you put out a call
For volunteers for the first crew to Mars
They'd be lined up coast to coast

[Sagan]
Mars is a world of wonders

[Cox]
It has canyons, river valleys,
and giant ice sheets

[Sagan]
Mars is a world of wonders

[Zubrin]
It shouldn't be humans to Mars in 50 years
It should be humans to Mars in 10

[Cox]
Mars is a dry frozen version of our home
Covered in red dust and sand

[Penelope Boston]
At one time
In the ancient past
Mars was very similar
To the conditions of early earth

[Zubrin]
There will always be people with new ideas
On how humans should live together

[Cox]
We now have "eyes" and "ears" on the surface

[Zubrin]
What's left after you go is
The good you've left behind
You have to believe in hope
You have to believe in the future
There are more and more people coming around to the point of view that
A positive future for humanity requires human expansion to space

[Sagan]
Mars is a world of wonders

[Cox]
It has canyons, river valleys,
and giant ice sheets

[Sagan]
Mars is a world of wonders

[Zubrin]
It shouldn't be humans to Mars in 50 years
It should be humans to Mars in 10

[Sagan]
This is a world of wonders

[Zubrin]
We're at a crossroads today
We either muster the courage to go
Or we risk the possibility of stagnation and decay
Thanks to Filipe Calvario! (123Calvario)

title: Symphony of Science - 'The Case for Mars'  (ft. Zubrin, Sagan, Cox & Boston)

comments.text: The Case for Mars...﻿
comments.author: Koleksi FLAC

comments.text:
I think there are some serious concerns for the long term habitability of 
Mars.
Consider that Antarctica has been explored for well over 100 years and yet 
it has zero permanent residents. Down there the temperatures are comparable 
to the surface of mars and there is actually an atmosphere you can breathe. 
I am not saying at all that we shouldn't be exploring mars right now, quite 
the contrary. I am just concerned that it may be a little illusory to say 
we can settle it with current technology if nobody is even bothering to set 
up permanent homes on numerous places back here on earth.﻿
comments.author: Reilly Jensen

comments.text: MarsOne=  Ponzi Scheme scam﻿
comments.author: Neueregel

comments.text:
Perhaps, when we figure out how to trap magnetic pulses, we can reanimate 
mars by putting back its magnetic field. A sort of jump start, if you will. 
If we do this, we can repopulate this ancient extinct planet, and rather 
from it being a dusty wasteland, perhaps we can make a new home that is 
suitable here. I mean, the orbit around the sun allows it to be the 
necessary temperature to life. But that doesn't mean that life needs our 
requirements. Chemosynthesis may occur on mars, but more of a twist than 
earth. Perhaps rather then volcanic vents in H2O, perhaps radiation from 
the sun can help Chemosynthesis occur. We don't know that for sure, but 
perhaps it is. We won't know, until we actually investigate this 
post-apocalyptic wasteland.﻿

comments.text:
1. Darwin was a Christian most of his life, he became an atheist/agnostic 
after the church got mad at him, and after doing the important stuff he did.
2. CERN simply doesn't use enough energy to destroy the planet. The worst 
case scenario would be to brake cern, which kind if renders your point mute.
3. While original ideas can come from those without official educations, 
that is rare, and becoming rarer. As more and more of the low hanging fruit 
is picked, more and more knowledge is needed for new discoveries. Yes, 
institutions can only teach knowable and not intelligence, but you need 
knowledge. 
4. Yes, scientists are just people, and yes some are total bastards who 
steel credit. But no one is claiming they aren't just people. Ultimately, 
it's not the scientists who matter. We don't know who invented the wheel 
and axel, or who discovered fire. We don't care, the wheel and fire are 
what is important, not their discoverers. The same will happen to Newton, 
Bour, Hawking and Feynman.

Heat is easy, use solar, geothermal or nuclear energy. As for coming back 
easy answer is they wont. Hard way is you can pre-send a return vehicle 
that can land VTOL and make fuel on site to escape the gravity-well. Now 
that I think about it the landing half is awfully close to what SpaceX is 
doing with its rockets... But as for not coming back, we would have to be 
able to live off the land with total self reliance off a totally dead 
planet, no taking shortcuts with Earth biosphere and abusing it. That 
self-reliance I think is the true "Case for Mars"

oh it's very simple, the old too many eggs one basket analogy.

comments.author: XminecraftsniperX

comments.text:
Of all of these videos I have watched, I have loved, except this one.

From an ecological standpoint, what Robert Zubrin wants here is disastrous. 
The reason why we have a problem with overexpansion in terms of population 
is because WE KEEP EXPANDING. Going to Mars would not help with our 
overexpansion, it would make it worse. If living on another planet sounds 
fantastic, you are right: it's a fantasy. We can't give up on our world.

That said, exploring Mars is a great idea! Such a source of research and 
discovery is good, as long as we don't abuse it (for example, by claiming 
Mars for ourselves).

If you have read Ishmael by Daniel Quinn, or if you are an attentive 
student of ecology, you know what I'm writing about here.
comments.author: Jasper Shehane

comments.text:
it's really simple, the preservation of the species, Survival, Evolution 
states that a species must grow and adapt to survive, well we have the 
opportunity to adapt in a way that no other species on this planet can, by 
spreading ourselves to other worlds we ensure our survival even in the 
worst of circumstances.

mars is just the first step, our tutorial, our trial if you will, to step 
out into the vastness of space and expand among the stars, and once we are 
spread out enough, not even a black hole running through our home star 
system will take us down, only the destruction of the universe, or by 
another intelligence can do that at that point.
comments.author: SpookyZalost

just the first step in a long line of inhabiting other planets.

comments.author: KASASpace

comments.text:
well yeah it's not essential, but consider this.
rig up an automated mining system in the asteroid belt which is closer to 
mars than earth.
use that to construct it, the excess material provides a profitable return 
for the cost in energy and resources put in, plus you've then got an 
asteroid mining setup for anything else!
honestly I don't see it as such a bad idea... do you have a better way to 
give mars an EM field to help with radiation issues and such?
y'know short of collecting a large mass of objects to try to 
gravitationally jump start it's core... 
honestly this is the best way to provide one given the technology and 
potential resources available, and the one that wastes the least amount of 
energy!

also, it'll take 70 to 100 years at least to terraform mars to a 
comfortable level regardless, so why not put something that'll help rather 
than hinder the terraforming process in the first place?
comments.author: SpookyZalost

it's actually easier than you think, a web of geostationary satellites with 
enough energy could create an artificial magnetic bubble around the planet

comments.author: SpookyZalost

comments.text:
No need to tackle the magnetic field issue until its been terraformed, rate 
of atmospheric striping is very slow.
The fastest way to terraform would be industrial CFC production, 
ammonia/ice meteor bombardment, nuking the south pole or solar mirrors.
Microbes need to wait until we have at least outgassed some captured CO2.
comments.author: HALL9000ish

comments.text:
Marte este urmatorul pas firesc in programul nostru spatial.
Este provocarea ce ne priveste fix in fata de 30 de ani.
Are apa, are carbon, are ziua de 24 de ore, are energie geo-termala.
Marte este un loc unde ne putem stabili asezari.

Are o fisura imensa, lunga de 5000 de km, care ii spinteca suprafata.
Are un vulcan larg cat statul Arizona. (aprox. 500km)

Deci exista aceasta alegere in viata: fie cresti fie te degradezi.
Cresti sau mori.
Eu cred ca ar trebui sa crestem.

Marte este o lume plina de minuni.

Are canioane, vai de rauri, si ghetari imensi.

Marte este o lume plina de minuni.

Nu ar trebui sa ne gandim cum sa trimitem oameni pe Marte peste 50 de ani,
ci peste 10 ani!

Fie ne adunam curajul sa mergem, fie riscam sa stagnam.

Exista radiatie cosmica, lipsa gravitatiei, furtuni de nisip, contaminare, 
dar
acestia sunt dragoni pe care noi putem sa ii infruntam.

In vremea noastra, am cernut nisipul Martian, ne-am stabilit prezenta acolo,
si ne-am indeplinit un secol de visuri.

Robotii de pe marte, cu adevarat, ne-au captivat imaginatia.
Ei sunt veritabili exploratori, precum exploratorii de odinioara.

Daca am pune anunt ca adunam voluntari pentru primul echipaj catre Marte,
s-ar face coada de la coasta de est a SUA pana la coasta de vest! (aprox. 
3347km)﻿

space, and yet one of the greatest obstacles is ourselves as a species. ﻿

comments.text:
He's upset that we're not on Mars already.  He's been pushing for it for 
decades, and the space program never made a serious try at sending humans 
there.  I understand his frustration--for a fraction of what we've spent on 
war in the last decade we could easily be there.  I still think it will 
happen, but by then Zubrin will be too old to go, and he's furious about 
that.

comments.author: shunos

comments.text:
One thing we could do to establish a "permanent" magnetic field is take 
material from the asteroid belt or else where and smash it into mars, 
adding to the planets mass. this would allow it to hold heat better and if 
under the proper circumstances where the core heats up and begins 
projecting a magnetic field, the planet would be nothing more than a cold, 
dry, red Earth and terraforming at that point would be as simple as taking 
paint and throwing it on an easel.
comments.author: Daniel Gillespie

comments.text:
Step one to successfully colonizing mars would be to establish a planetary 
magnetic field to block the solar radiation. Step two would be the process 
of producing a thicker atmosphere which would prosper with the suns 
onslaught halted. In a short time mars would begin to form habitable 
features and earth-like weather systems.
comments.author: Daniel Gillespie

comments.text:
While terraforming is the key to our colonization of mars, our attempts at 
producing a habitable atmosphere would be a waste of recourses due to the 
lack of a viable magnetic field to shield the planet from the solar wind. 
Most of the material that we would pump into the atmosphere to enhance it 
would be picked of by solar radiation. this is why the Martian atmosphere 
is so thin today.
comments.author: Daniel Gillespie

comments.text: Ok.
comments.author: magnusbjarnisk

comments.text:
There are two was to get to Mars: a long and a short way. The long way is 
the one you're talking about with a long trip to Mars and short stay. The 
short way is the one I'm talking about with a short trip to Mars and a long 
stay. The ISS is meant to have regular supply shipments, so they don't keep 
large stocks on the ISS. It's the difference between living on a small 
island and camping.
comments.author: kokofan50

comments.text:
I didn't say terraforming would be done in 50 year but the first part of it 
might. No matter where we try colonizing it's going to take some effort and 
money. Also, if you think warp drives are going to happen in this life time 
you're crazy. A space elevator would be great, but who knows how long that 
will take if ever happens.
comments.author: kokofan50

comments.text:
It would in fact be harder to reach Mars with a manned mission now than the 
moon in 1969. The reason? Time. It took about 1 or 2 weeks to reach the 
moon and back. That is like a vacation. To reach to Mars and back? That 
requires at minimum 2 1/2 years with only 1 month on the surface. And the 
ISS gets supplies every 6 months because it is not large enough to carry 
more. So Mars mission would have to have a tiny ecosystem and the ship 
would also have to be huge...
comments.author: magnusbjarnisk

comments.text:
Yes, I am a fan of terraforming - But that won't happen within 50 years, 
now will it? Digging the cities would also take a long time, and we would 
need so many vehicles and robots the launch costs would likely be extremely 
large. Plus, the pure resource requirement of a large - scale settlement 
will probably be possible within a couple decades, but by then we should be 
able to find a better place to settle using warp drives. Plus, space 
elevators. Useful, eh?
comments.author: dzarko55

comments.text:
Like I said before we could dig the cities in to the ground on Mars. 
Another option is to thicken Mars' atmosphere before large scale 
migration-- if you look in to it that's not as crazy as it sounds-- and the 
first step in terraforming Mars-- I count terraforming as part of truly 
colonizing Mars. Most people spent the majority of their life's fortune 
going to the west in the beginning. We can grow food in green houses and 
extract water from the soil on Mars.
comments.author: kokofan50

comments.text:
Actually, it took much longer than 35 years, in fact 3.5 million years when 
humans first stared using tools. Also, the basic technology of the liquid 
fueled rocket was invent by Robert Goddard, or the basic technology of the 
rocket it self was invent by the Chinese thousand of years ago. I'm not 
trying to be an ass, just making a point. With the technology base they had 
at the start of the space race, we got to the moon in ten years, which was 
much harder than it would be to get to Mars now.
comments.author: kokofan50

comments.text:
Actually, it took much longer than 10 years. Humans first stepped on the 
moon in 1969. The basic technology behind the rockets that got them there 
was developed in 1934, by Wernher von Braun(who's plan was to send men to 
other bodies in space, which he succeeded to do with the Saturn V). It took 
35 years, one world war and a cold war to get from 2 rockets that reached 
heights of 2.2 and 3.5 km to get to one that reached 384,403 km. The first 
digital computer was invented in 1940.
comments.author: magnusbjarnisk

comments.text:
If you put out a call for volunteers for the first crew to Mars, they would 
not only line up from the Pacific to the Atlantic... They would line up 
from the Eastern to the Western pacific.
comments.author: dzarko55

comments.text:
Remember, I'm talking about both radiation on the way from Mars and a 
prolonged stay there. Because you aren't coming back, most likely. The old 
west was different; Anyone could, technically, go and live there. Every 
person sent to space costs tens of thousands, not including food, drink and 
similar. Now, remember, I want cities on Mars. I just want you to convince 
me your arguments are valid, so I can agree.
comments.author: dzarko55

comments.text:
Dr. Tyson could be, or he could have been speaking loosely for a general 
audience. You're right there are technologies that need invented. However, 
those technologies will never be invented with out a need for them, and the 
number of technologies that need to be invent are much fewer than when we 
went to the moon, which took only 10 year.
comments.author: kokofan50

comments.text:
Oh, so Dr. Tyson is wrong? He said a manned mission would take 
approximately 3-4 years (that is, if you want to be longer than just 1 
month, which then would take 2 1/2 years). And by my knowledge and 
calculations (that are not very accurate), it would require some major 
preparation to send a manned mission to Mars. It also requires technology 
that we do not yet have. Perhaps, by working with other space programs, 
humans can step on Mars in at least 30 years.
comments.author: magnusbjarnisk

comments.text:
A number of Cosmonauts and Astronauts have gotten higher radiation doses 
that what would happen on the way to Mars, and are doing just fine. You're 
right about the launch costs if I was talking about cities as we know them 
now. Why can't have the space equivalent of the old west ten cities with 
inflatables? Also, why not underground cities on Mars?
comments.author: kokofan50

comments.text:
I don't know where you got the idea that a Mars mission would take 4 year 
but it's wrong. A Mars mission would only last 2 1/2 years. If we go with a 
plan like Mars direct, which I think we should, we would have to have three 
launches of some in the range of the Saturn V or SLS.
comments.author: kokofan50

comments.text:
I read an article in a science magazine some time ago where they explained 
that cancer was only one of many concerns regarding space radiation. It 
also includes damage to the nervous system, and travelling to Mars will 
most likely kill 5% of the cells in your body without more protection than 
we currently have. Launch costs are a serious issue, because larger crafts 
are required to make a city. Unless you mine it all, which takes a lot more 
time than you'd expect.
comments.author: dzarko55
